Boltzmann constant, and temperature, respectively. The high diffusion constant corresponds to the fast migration of Na ions, leading to high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ion-current" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">We then evaluate the maximum Na capacity of tC40 by gradually intercalating Na ions into the tC40 substrate and observing the corresponding voltage profile. To obtain a more precise result of the voltage profile, a 1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3 supercell of tC40 is used for the voltage calculation. The results plotted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(h) show that the voltage decreases monotonically with increasing sodium <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ion-concentration" title="Learn more about ion concentration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ion concentration</a>. The adsorption of Na ions in this substrate tends to become energetically unfavorable when the voltage approaches zero, which corresponds to a maximum reversible capacity of 186 mAhÂ·g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>. We use the formula [<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-94-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">c</mi></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">E</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mi is="true">c</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-94"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mtext is="true">formation</mtext></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">c</mi></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mi is="true">c</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">âˆ’</mo><mi is="true">c</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span>, <em>c</em><span><span> is Na concentration] to determine the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/energy-of-formation" title="Learn more about formation energy of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">formation energy of</a> tC40 during charging and discharging. It involves the calculations of the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/calorific-value" title="Learn more about energy values from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy values</a> of Na-intercalated tC40 at different concentrations of sodium ions with </span><em>c</em> ranging from 0 to 1. The resulting ground-state hull diagram is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(g), showing that the intermediate state with the highest stability is also the thermodynamic <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ground-state" title="Learn more about ground state from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ground state</a> for each concentration of Na ions, as indicated by the convexity of the hull.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">To evaluate the open-circuit voltage (OCV) of tC40, we examine six intermediate Na-intercalated concentrations, i.e. Na<sub><em>x</em></sub>C<sub>12</sub>, <em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.6, and 0.9, respectively. For each concentration, we generate possible intermediate structures with low energies by comparing the Ewald energies implemented in the pymatgen package [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. Then the OCV is calculated by using the formula:<span class="display"><span id="fd25" class="formula"><span class="label">(25)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mtext is="true">Na</mtext></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-98"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mtext is="true">Na</mtext></msub></mrow></math></script></span> represent the energies of <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-99-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>x</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.384ex" height="1.74ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 1026.4 749.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-78"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(572,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-99"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span> Na-, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-100-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>x</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.384ex" height="1.74ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 1026.4 749.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-78"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(572,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-100"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span> Na-intercalated tC40, and one Na atom in its bulk phase, respectively. The voltage profile of tC40 is displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(h), where the voltage is positive through the entire concentration region, suggesting that the capacity of 186 mAhÂ·g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is reversible. The average OCV of 0.38&nbsp;V is relatively low as compared to that of some other anode materials, such as oC46 (0.43&nbsp;V) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>], tC<sub>24</sub> (0.54&nbsp;V) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], <em>1T</em>-MoS<sub>2</sub> (1.25&nbsp;V), <em>2H</em>â€“MoS<sub>2</sub> (0.75&nbsp;V) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>], and ISN (1.35&nbsp;V) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>]. Indeed, the voltage is related to the derivative of formation energy with respect to Na concentration, rather than the formation energy itself. The low average OCV of an anode could provide a high output voltage when connected to a cathode.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">In addition, the volume change during the charging/discharging process is also important for the cycling stability of a battery. Therefore, we further calculate the volume change by using the formula: <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-101-Frame" is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></msub></mrow><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo><mn xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="21.103ex" height="3.932ex" viewBox="0 -1094.9 9086.2 1693.1" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.389ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3A9"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1897,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(831,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1382,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" is="true" transform="translate(5750,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6751,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="500" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="1001" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8252,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-25"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Î”</mo><mi is="true">Î©</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mrow><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">Ã—</mo><mn is="true">100</mn><mo is="true">%</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-101"><math><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Î”</mo><mi is="true">Î©</mi></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mrow><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">Ã—</mo><mn is="true">100</mn><mo is="true">%</mo></mrow></math></script></span>, here <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-102-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.732ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1176.4 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(722,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-102"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-103-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.732ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1176.4 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(722,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-103"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span> are the volumes of the fully-Na-intercalated and non-Na-intercalated tC40 configurations. The volume change of tC40 is calculated to be 0.79&nbsp;%, which is lower than oC46 (2.0&nbsp;%) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>] and ISN (2.8&nbsp;%) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>], showing higher stability due to the less volume change during charging-discharging operation.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The potential of tC40 as a SIB anode material, especially its high reversible capacity and low diffusion energy barrier for Na ions, suggest that the porous structure and topological nodal-surface states of tC40 play a crucial role not only in accommodating and transporting Na ions effectively, but also in mitigating common challenges faced by battery anodes, such as rapid capacity fade [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a><span><span>]. Moreover, the low average OCV is beneficial for enhancing the <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> in the full-cell application, and small volume change during charging-discharging cycles further demonstrates the good performance of tC40 as an anode for </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150"><span>In summary, we have theoretically predicted a new porous carbon <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/honeycomb-structure" title="Learn more about honeycomb structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">honeycomb structure</a><span>, tC40, by using graphene nanoribbons as the building block, which is stable and metallic. More interestingly, we find that tC40 possesses exotic nodal surface states including four-fold and two-fold degeneracies, and the two-fold degenerated nodal surface is formed by the essential degeneracy of valence and conduction bands based on the analysis of the crystalline symmetries in irreducible representation. This mechanism is different from that of other topological nodal <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about surface carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface carbon</a> materials reported so far. As a SIB anode material, tC40 possesses a high reversible capacity of 186 mAhÂ·g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, a low diffusion energy barrier of 0.1&nbsp;eV for Na ions, a low OCV of 0.38&nbsp;V, and a neglectable volume change of 0.79&nbsp;%. Our work provides a study of using topological nodal surface carbon as the anode material, shedding light on the development of next generation SIB anodes.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><strong>Dongyuan Ni:</strong> Conceptualization, Methodology, Software, Writing â€“ original draft, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Wei Sun:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Shang Gao:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Qian Wang:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">This work is partially supported by grants from the <span id="gs1">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">NSFC-11974028</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">NSFC-12274007</span></span></a>) and <span id="gs2">the National Key Research and Development Program of the Ministry of Science and Technology of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2021YFB4000601</span></span></a>). It is also supported by <span id="gs4">the High-Performance Computing Platform of Peking University, China</span>.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="appsec1"><h2 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Sun, <em> et al.</em></div><div id="ref-id-sref56" class="title text-m">Lithium chlorides and bromides as promising solid-state chemistries for fast ion conductors with good electrochemical stability</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Angew. Qie, J. Liu, X. Li, S. Wang, Q. Sun, P. Jena</div><div id="ref-id-sref58" class="title text-m">Interpenetrating silicene networks: a topological nodal-line semimetal with potential as an anode material for sodium ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Phys. Rev. Mater., 2 (2018), Article 084201</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85059637196&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Interpenetrating%20silicene%20networks%3A%20a%20topological%20nodal-line%20semimetal%20with%20potential%20as%20an%20anode%20material%20for%20sodium%20ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2018&amp;author=Y.%20Qie&amp;author=J.%20Liu&amp;author=X.%20Li&amp;author=S.%20Wang&amp;author=Q.%20Sun&amp;author=P.%20Jena" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbib59" id="ref-id-bib59" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sref59"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">Z. Liu, X.-Y. Yu, X.W. Lou, U. Paik</div><div id="ref-id-sref59" class="title text-m">Sb@C coaxial nanotubes as a superior long-life and high-rate anode for sodium ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Energy Environ. Sci., 9 (2016), pp. 2314-2318</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-84978426899&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=SbC%20coaxial%20nanotubes%20as%20a%20superior%20long-life%20and%20high-rate%20anode%20for%20sodium%20ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2016&amp;author=Z.%20Liu&amp;author=X.-Y.%20Yu&amp;author=X.W.%20Lou&amp;author=U.%20Paik" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sref59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (4)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X25002816"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Boosting the cyclability and electrochemical kinetics of Na&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;MnV(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;/C cathode material through Zr doping for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Energy Storage</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0065">Na<sub>4</sub>MnV(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NMVP) cathode material has been regarded as a potential substitute for Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> because of the lower cost and toxicity, and higher operating voltage. However, the electrochemical performance of NMVP is hindered by the extremely low electrical conductivity and Jahn-Teller distortion induced by Mn(III). To boost the electrochemical kinetics of NMVP and mitigate the detrimental impacts of Jahn-Teller distortion, the smaller Mn<sup>2+</sup> is substituted by larger Zr<sup>4+</sup>, and Na<sub>4-2x</sub>Mn<sub>1-x</sub>Zr<sub>x</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (with x increasing from 0.05 to 0.13) cathode materials were synthesized by a sol-gel method. Zr doping expands the channel for Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion and improves the diffusion coefficients of sodium ion, rate performance and cycle performance of NMVP/C. The initial discharge capacities of the optimal Zr-doped NMVP/C (Na<sub>3.82</sub>Mn<sub>0.91</sub>Zr<sub>0.09</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C) and NMVP/C electrodes cycled at 0.2C (22.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) between 2.5 and 3.8&nbsp;V are 98 and 93.8 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively, and the matching capacity retentions are 97.8&nbsp;% and 65.2&nbsp;% after 100&nbsp;cycles. Even at 10C between 2.5 and 3.8&nbsp;V, the initial discharge capacity of Na<sub>3.82</sub>Mn<sub>0.91</sub>Zr<sub>0.09</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (87.4 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) is significantly larger than that of NMVP/C (71.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), at the same time, the capacity retention of Na<sub>3.82</sub>Mn<sub>0.91</sub>Zr<sub>0.09</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C is 92.1&nbsp;% after 500&nbsp;cycles, also remarkably larger than that of NMVP/C (78.2&nbsp;%). When electrodes were cycled between 2.5 and 4.3&nbsp;V at 10C (1670&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), the capacity retention of 77.4&nbsp;% was obtained for Na<sub>3.82</sub>Mn<sub>0.91</sub>Zr<sub>0.09</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C after 100&nbsp;cycles and the corresponding residual discharge capacity is 76 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, whereas NMVP/C delivers low capacity retention (43.9&nbsp;%) and low residual discharge capacity (53 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>).</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1369800124008060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Breaking new ground in metal-ion battery anodes: First principles design of Dirac nodal line semimetallic carbon materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Materials Science in Semiconductor Processing</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Compared with lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion, and potassium-ion batteries need to be further improved in terms of anode battery materials. For SIBs, Ni et al. proposed a 3D carbon honeycomb structure (tC40) [16] for SIBs with an extremely low theoretical capacity of 186 mA h/g, such lower theoretical capacity limits its wide application. Relatively little attention has been paid to potassium-ion batteries (KIBs).</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">With the rapid development of electronic devices, the demand for batteries has gradually increased, and existing batteries can no longer satisfy it. In this paper, a three-dimensional honeycomb carbon material is designed and termed pmma-C32. The mechanical stability, dynamic stability, thermal stability, and mechanical stability were investigated through first-principles molecular dynamics, phonon spectrum, and the Born-Huangkun criterion. The calculation results show that pmma-C32 not only has good thermodynamic stability, but also has static stability. Similar to graphene, pmma-C32 exhibits semi-metallic characteristics, featuring two Dirac node lines with high Fermi velocity, indicating a high capacity for electron transport. As a metal-ion battery material, pmma-C32 exhibits higher theoretical capacity(836.8, 732.2, and 418.4&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h/g for Li, Na, and K), lower diffusion barrier (0.06â€“0.12&nbsp;eV for Li, 0.10â€“0.11&nbsp;eV for Na, and 0.05â€“0.06&nbsp;eV for K), and lower open circuit voltage (0.34&nbsp;V for Li, 0.37&nbsp;V for Na, and 0.74&nbsp;V for K). These remarkable properties endow semimetallic pmma-C32 as a promising anode material for metal-ion batteries, providing fast charge and discharge rates. This research not only broadens the family of three-dimensional carbon materials, but also greatly improves the performance for universal metal-ion battery anode materials through material structure design.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X2403370X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Structure-mechanisms-performance relation of 3D carbon material for alkali metal-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">For lithium-ion batteries, Imm2-C16 exhibits a theoretical capacity approximately three times higher than that of graphite. Moreover, the theoretical capacities for sodium and potassium ions are also superior to those of other three-dimensional carbon-based materials (hC28 for SIBs 717 mAh/g [37]; tC40 for SIBs 186 mAh/g [38]; Bco-C24 for PIBs 371.9 mAh/g [14]; B2N2 for SIBs/PIBs 599.90/479.92mAh/g [39]). Compared with other alkaline earth metal ion batteries, B2P2 with high capacity of SIBs/PIBs 904.00/691.30 mA h/g, but lower capacity of LIBs 691.30 mA h/g [40], a similar result can also be found in SIC [41].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0045">Alkali metal-ion batteries have attracted considerable attention as promising energy storage devices. However, the design of three-dimensional carbon materials for alkali metal-ion batteries remains a significant challenge. Inspired by the experimental synthesis of three-dimensional carbon honeycomb structures, this study introduces a novel carbon material exhibiting metallic properties, named <em>Imm2</em>-C16. Its structured arrangement and pore sizes contribute to higher theoretical capacity 1115.7 mAh/g for lithium-ion batteries, 836.8 mAh/g for sodium-ion batteries, and 488.1 mAh/g for potassium-ion batteries, lower diffusion barriers(0.11â€“0.22, 0.06â€“0.19, 0.02â€“0.06&nbsp;eV for Li/Na/K-ion batteries) and open circuit voltages (0.36&nbsp;V for lithium ions, 0.47&nbsp;V for sodium ions, and 0.61&nbsp;V), showcasing exceptional performance as a anode material for alkali metal-ion batteries. Additionally, a simple model is established to provide a threshold for the pore size of metal-ion batteries, which also provides a reliable basis for the design of three-dimensional carbon materials as alkali metal-ion batteries. This study not only presents a novel anode material design but also elucidates corresponding storage mechanisms, offering valuable insights for the advancement of the next generation of alkali metal-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsaem.3c02743" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Mn-Ni Foreign Ions Codoping Polyanionic Iron-Based Compounds of Na&lt;inf&gt;3.12&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;2.44&lt;/inf&gt;(P&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;7&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; for Long-Life and High-Rate Sodium-Ion Battery Cathode</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, ACS Applied Energy Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S000862232300800X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">Â© 2023 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=recommended-articles:type=close"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><h2 class="section-title u-h4"><span class="related-content-panel-title-text">Recommended articles</span></h2></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article0-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0008622323008163" title="Dielectric loss compensation induced by hydroxyl surface grafting protects against microwave absorption attenuation"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Dielectric loss compensation induced by hydroxyl surface grafting protects against microwave absorption attenuation</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Carbon, Volume 216, 2024, Article 118571</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Haoshan</span> <span>Jin</span>, â€¦, <span>Bo</span> <span>Ouyang</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S0008622323008163/pdfft?md5=62e38fddb21007136e98a003c900b19a&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S0008622323008163-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
