text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010"><span>Motivated by the successful synthesis of three-dimensional (3D) graphene monoliths, we propose a 3D carbon <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/honeycomb-structure" title="Learn more about honeycomb structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">honeycomb structure</a>, tC40, composed of graphene-nanoribbons linked with 5-5-8 defects based on first-principles calculations. This structure is not only dynamically, thermally, and mechanically stable, but also possesses interesting electronic properties, including the multiple topological nodal surfaces on the high-symmetry plane </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.526ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2810 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1253,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2309,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></script></span> with double and quadruple degeneracies of bands in the reciprocal space, and the nontrivial surface states connecting different topological nodal surfaces parallel to the <em>z</em>-axis. By using the <strong><em>k</em></strong>Â·<strong><em>p</em></strong> model, we further show that, unlike previously reported nodal surfaces, the energy dispersion of the quadruply degenerated nodal surface is proportional to the <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.32ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 1429.3 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,421)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span><span><span>, while the Hamiltonian of the doubly degenerated nodal surface is formed by the essential degeneracy of the valence and <a href="/topics/chemistry/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction bands from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction bands</a><span>. In addition, we explore the application of this nodal <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about surface carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface carbon</a> as an </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and find that tC40 exhibits good performance with a high reversible capacity of 186 mAhÂ·g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, a low <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a><span> migration barrier of 0.1&nbsp;eV, and a small charging/discharging volume change of 0.79&nbsp;%. This work expands the family of topological <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon materials</a> and their applications in SIBs.</span></span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-ga1.jpg" height="175" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (548KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (548KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0008622323008114"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0008622323008163"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>3D porous carbon</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Topological nodal surface</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery anode</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010"><span><span>A topological material with nodal surfaces is a unique material where the band crossing points near the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/fermi-surface" title="Learn more about Fermi surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi surface</a> form multiple 2D surfaces, which not only enables the excitation of zero effective mass Dirac fermions, but also exhibits flat band characteristics with feature-rich electronic properties, making it promising for topological </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/superconductivity" title="Learn more about superconductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superconductivity</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span>], topologically protected <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/quantum-dot" title="Learn more about qubits from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">qubits</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>], nano-spintronics devices [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a><span>], and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/energy-storage-and-conversion" title="Learn more about energy conversion and storage from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy conversion and storage</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a><span>]. In recent years, a few topological nodal surface <a href="/topics/chemistry/metalloid" title="Learn more about semimetals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">semimetals</a> including Ti</span><sub>3</sub>Al [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>], LiTiO<sub>2</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>], and Sr<sub>5</sub>X<sub>3</sub> (X&nbsp;=&nbsp;As, Sb, Bi) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>] compounds have been theoretically predicted, and Dirac nodal surfaces and nodal rings in NaAlSi [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>] and ZrSiS [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a><span>] have been experimentally observed. <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about Carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Carbon materials</a> have also received considerable attention in the field of topological electronics due to the flexible bonding and orbital hybridization of carbon atoms. As a result, a number of semimetallic carbon allotropes have been identified, including 2D Dirac semimetallic carbon (like graphene [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>], Stone-Wales graphene [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>], OPG-Z [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>], and <em>Î±</em>-graphyne [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>]) and 3D topological nodal-line carbon (like bco-C<sub>16</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>], oP16 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>], and ors-C<sub>16</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>]). Carbon materials also provide an appropriate platform for the formation of topological nodal surface states due to weak spin-orbit coupling (SOC), which was illustrated by low-energy tight-binding models [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>]. So far, a few semimetallic carbon materials with nodal surfaces have been proposed, including TGN (2, 2) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>], CNTN (<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], and tC<sub>24</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>]. The research on carbon-based topological nodal surfaces is still in its early stage, and further theoretical and experimental exploration is needed.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015"><span>On the other hand, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been extensively studied as an alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in recent years, because <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span><span><span> is more abundant, more environmentally friendly, and safer as compared to lithium. However, graphite, commonly used as the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for LIBs, is facing significant challenges when repurposed for SIBs, such as structural instability, low </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>, and slow charge/discharge rates associated with the large size of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a>. The capacity is only 35 mAhÂ·g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> when graphite is used as the anode material for SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a><span><span>]. Therefore, many efforts have been made to develop 3D <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a> allotropes composed of graphene </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about nanoribbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoribbons</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span>] and 3D porous topological metallic/semi-metallic carbon for metal-ion <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> anodes [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>], because large regular pores can provide more adsorption sites and transport channels for metal ions, and the high electronic conductivity resulting from the topological metallicity/semi-metallicity can improve the rate performance of batteries [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><span>In this study, we propose a new stable 3D porous honeycomb carbon, tC40, by using double-benzene-ring-width graphene <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about nanoribbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoribbons</a> as the building block. Based on state-of-the-art theoretical calculations and analysis, we demonstrate that this structure possesses topological nodal surface electronic states protected by the essential degeneracy of valence and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction bands from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction bands</a>, and further show that tC40 is a promising candidate for SIB anode material.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Computational methods</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025"><span>Our calculations are based on <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about density functional theory from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density functional theory</a> (DFT) as implemented in the Vienna </span><em>ab initio</em> simulation package (VASP) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a><span>]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/pseudopotential" title="Learn more about pseudopotential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudopotential</a> is used to treat ion-electron interactions [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>] with a large energy cutoff of 800&nbsp;eV. The exchange-correlation interactions of electrons are described by adopting the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>]. The more accurate Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof hybrid functional (HSE06) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a><span>] is used for calculating <a href="/topics/materials-science/electronic-band-structure" title="Learn more about electronic band structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic band structure</a> to avoid the systematic underestimation of band gaps of the PBE functional. The convergence criteria are set as 10</span><sup>âˆ’4</sup>&nbsp;eV and 10<sup>âˆ’2</sup>&nbsp;eVÃ…<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> for energy and force, respectively. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/phonon" title="Learn more about phonon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phonon</a> frequencies are obtained by using the finite displacement method [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>] implemented in the Phonopy package [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a><span>], and in <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/phonon" title="Learn more about phonon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phonon</a> calculations, the corresponding criteria for energy and force during structural optimization are set to 10</span><sup>âˆ’8</sup>&nbsp;eV and 10<sup>âˆ’6</sup>&nbsp;eVÃ…<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. <em>Ab initio</em><span> molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations are performed to verify the thermal stability within the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/canonical-ensemble" title="Learn more about canonical ensemble from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">canonical ensemble</a>, where the temperature is controlled by the NosÃ© thermostat [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a><span>]. To examine the mechanical stability, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/elasticity" title="Learn more about elastic constants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elastic constants</a> are calculated by using the energy-strain method in the AELAS package [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a><span>]. The surface states are obtained from the iterative <a href="/topics/chemistry/tight-binding-model" title="Learn more about Green's function from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Green's function</a> method using the Wannier90 [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>] and WannierTools [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>] packages. The irreducible representations are identified by the Irvsp package [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a><span><span>]. In the calculations of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of the anode, the effect of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/van-der-waals-force" title="Learn more about van der Waals interactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">van der Waals interactions</a> is taken into consideration by using the PBE-D2 functional [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. The diffusion energy barrier for Na-ion migration is calculated by using the climbing-image nudge elastic band (CI-NEB) method [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>].</div></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Structure and stability</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0030">The successful synthesis of 3D graphene monoliths [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span><span>] demonstrates that graphene <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about nanoribbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoribbons</a> can be used as the building blocks to design and synthesize 3D porous </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon materials</a>, where the </span><em>sp</em><sup>3</sup> bonding is essential to retain the stability of carbon-honeycomb structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a><span>]. Thus, various 3D <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a><span> materials can be rationally designed by using different widths, lengths, and morphologies of carbon <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about nanoribbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoribbons</a> with </span></span><em>sp</em><sup>3</sup><span>-hybridized carbon as the linkers. Different from previously studied topological nodal <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about surface carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface carbon</a> tC</span><sub>24</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>], in this work, we use the experimentally observed 5-5-8 carbon line-defects [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>] as the linkers for assembling zigzag graphene nanoribbons, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>. The resulting 3D carbon allotrope contains 40 atoms in its unit cell with the <a href="/topics/chemistry/trigonal-space-group" title="Learn more about trigonal space group from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">trigonal space group</a> </span><em>P</em>-3<em>m</em><span>1 (No. 164), thus termed tC40. The optimized <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice constants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice constants</a> are </span><em>a</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;13.76&nbsp;Ã… and <em>c</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;4.89&nbsp;Ã…, and there are eight chemically nonequivalent Wickoff positions in its unit cell, occupying 6<em>i</em><sub>1</sub> (0.5731, 0.4269, 0.1263), 6<em>i</em><sub>2</sub> (0.5778, 0.4222, 0.6242), 6<em>i</em><sub>3</sub> (0.3952, 0.6047, 0.1172), 6<em>i</em><sub>4</sub> (0.6051, 0.395, 0.3674), 6<em>i</em><sub>5</sub> (0.5137, 0.4864, 0.1271), 6<em>i</em><sub>6</sub> (0.484, 0.5161, 0.377), 2<em>d</em><sub>1</sub> (0.3333, 0.6667, 0.0433), and 2<em>d</em><sub>2</sub> (0.3333, 0.6667, 0.7073), respectively. Detailed information of the tC40's structure can be found in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supplementary Information (SI)</span></span></a>. Distinct from the previous carbon allotrope hC28 constructed by using single-benzene-ring-width zigzag graphene nanoribbon as its building block [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>], tC40 is composed of double-benzene-ring-width zigzag graphene nanoribbons with larger pore size of 15.94&nbsp;Ã…. The Câ€“C bond lengths between the three-fold coordinated atoms are calculated to be in the range of 1.40â€“1.47&nbsp;Ã…, comparable to that of graphite (1.42&nbsp;Ã…), while the bond length between the four-fold coordinated atoms is found to be 1.64&nbsp;Ã…, larger than that of diamond (1.53&nbsp;Ã…).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr1.jpg" height="368" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (698KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (698KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) Top view of the unit cell, (b) side view of the 1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;4 <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/supercell" title="Learn more about supercell from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercell</a>, and (c) perspective view of a 2&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;2&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;4 supercell of the tC40 structure. (A colour version of this figure can be viewed online.)</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0035">Next, we systematically examine the stability of tC40, including energetical, dynamical, thermal, and mechanical stabilities. We first calculate the energy-volume curve of tC40 and compare it with some other carbon allotropes, including Tri-C<sub>9</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>], T6 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>], H<sub>18</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>], K6 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>], penta-h22 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>], and the well-known 3D carbon, diamond and graphite. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(a), one can see that except for diamond and graphite, tC40 is energetically more favorable over the others, suggesting its energetical stability. The dynamical stability is examined by calculating its <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/phonon" title="Learn more about phonon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">phonon</a><span><span> spectrum. A 1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;2 <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/supercell" title="Learn more about supercell from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercell</a> is used to minimize the constraint of the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/periodic-boundary-condition" title="Learn more about periodic boundary conditions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">periodic boundary conditions</a>. The results plotted in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(b) show that no any imaginary frequencies exist in the first <a href="/topics/chemistry/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about Brillouin zone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Brillouin zone</a><span> (BZ), confirming that tC40 is dynamically stable. To examine the thermal stability, we perform the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-dynamics" title="Learn more about AIMD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">AIMD</a> calculations at 300 and 1200&nbsp;K respectively. The energy fluctuations within a heating time of 8 ps and a time step of 1 fs are plotted in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(c). The atomic configuration of tC40 keeps almost intact during the simulations, and the energies fluctuate around constant values at both 300 and 1200&nbsp;K, suggesting that the geometric structure is still secure at a high temperature of 1200&nbsp;K, then confirming the thermal stability of tC40.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr2.jpg" height="247" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (759KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (759KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) Energy-volume curves of the carbon allotropes. (b) Phonon spectrum of tC40 with the high-symmetry <strong><em>q</em></strong><span>-path in its first <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about BZ from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">BZ</a>. (c) Evolution of total potential energy of tC40 during AIMD simulations at 300 and 1200&nbsp;K with the inset snapshot for the atomic configuration at the end of the simulation at 1200&nbsp;K. (A colour version of this figure can be viewed online.)</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>In addition, mechanical stability is also an important indicator for the stability of a material. For tC40 with trigonal lattice, it has five independent <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/elasticity" title="Learn more about elastic constants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elastic constants</a>, which are calculated to be: </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>11</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.538ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1523.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(715,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">44</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">44</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;80.69&nbsp;GPa, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-6-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>12</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.538ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1523.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(715,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">12</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-6"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">12</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;116.3&nbsp;GPa, and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>13</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; These calculated <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/elasticity" title="Learn more about elastic constants from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elastic constants</a> fully satisfy the Born-Huang criteria [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>], namely, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>44</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.538ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 1523.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(715,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">33</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-13"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">33</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span> &gt;2<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-14-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>13</mn><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.538ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -896.2 1523.3 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.928ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(774,345)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(715,-308)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33" x="500" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">13</mn><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-14"><math><mrow is="true"><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">13</mn><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow></math></script></span><span><span>, therefore, tC40 is mechanically stable. Furthermore, the eigenvalues of the elastic <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/stiffness-matrix" title="Learn more about stiffness matrix from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stiffness matrix</a> for the systems optimized at temperatures of 300 and 1200&nbsp;K are respectively calculated, which are all positive, confirming the mechanical stability of tC40 at </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/finite-temperature" title="Learn more about finite temperatures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">finite temperatures</a>. The calculation details can be found in the SI.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">The exhibited good stability of tC40 can be attributed to the following reasons: (1) The composing units are stable: both the zigzag graphene nanoribbon and 5-5-8 line defect have been synthesized in experiments; (2) The <em>sp</em><sup>3</sup> bonding resulting from the assembling would further enhance the stability.</div></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electronic properties</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050"><span>We then systematically study the electronic properties of tC40. In the absence of <a href="/topics/chemistry/spin-orbit-coupling" title="Learn more about SOC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SOC</a><span>, the calculated <a href="/topics/chemistry/electronic-band-structure" title="Learn more about band structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">band structure</a> at the PBE level is plotted in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a), while the corresponding first BZ and high-symmetry <strong><em>k</em></strong>-point paths are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(b). The band crosses the <a href="/topics/chemistry/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a><span> along the Î“-A path, suggesting that tC40 is metallic. More interestingly, a flat band emerges near the Fermi level along the high-symmetry Î“-M-K-Î“ path. Since the PBE functional underestimates the band gap, to verify the metallic feature, we recalculate the band structure at the HSE06 level as well, and find that the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/metallicity" title="Learn more about metallicity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metallicity</a><span> still remains, and the flat band is slightly away from the Fermi level. The partial <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (PDOS) projected on the three-fold coordinated (</span></span></span><em>sp</em><sup>2</sup>) and four-fold coordinated (<em>sp</em><sup>3</sup>) carbon atoms plotted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) show that the main contribution to the bands near the Fermi level comes from the three-fold coordinated carbon atoms.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr3.jpg" height="610" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (925KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (925KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000862232300800X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span>(a) Electronic band structure and the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about PDOS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">PDOS</a> projected to the three- and four-fold coordinated carbon atoms. (b) First BZ with the high-symmetry </span><strong><em>k</em></strong><span>-paths and projected surface BZ for the (110) surface of tC40. (c) 3D band structure around the <a href="/topics/chemistry/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a> in the high-symmetry plane </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-15-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.526ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2810 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1253,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2309,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-15"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></script></span>. (d) Nodal surface distribution of the high-symmetry plane <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-16-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.526ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2810 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1253,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2309,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-16"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></script></span>. (e) Surface and (f) corresponding bulk spectra for the (110) surface of the tC40's unit cell.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">To further explore the energy dispersion details of the flat band, we calculate the 3D band structure of the high-symmetry plane <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-17-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; By computing the irreducible representations at the high-symmetry <strong><em>k</em></strong>-points, i.e. the Î“, M, and K points, we find that, at the Î“(0, 0, 0) point, the linear energy As we can see, the degeneracies are different at distinct <strong><em>k</em></strong>-points. To study the morphology of the band-crossing manifold, we scan the entire first BZ and plot the distribution of band-crossing points in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(d), which shows that there is a four-fold nodal surface around the Î“ point and a two-fold nodal <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/near-surface-geology" title="Learn more about surface near from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface near</a> the border of the first BZ.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">To gain insight into these nodal surfaces, we construct two <strong><em>k</em></strong>Â·<strong><em>p</em></strong> models around the high-symmetry <strong><em>k</em></strong> points, i.e. Î“ and K. Since the space group of tC40 is <em>P</em>-3<em>m</em>1, there are three symmetry operation generators, i.e. spatial inversion <em>P</em>, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-29-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; In addition, for nonmagnetic all-carbon materials, the time-reversal symmetry <em>T</em> is also preserved. Since at the Î“ point, the symmetry representation of the bands no.78-81 is <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-31-Frame" mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î“</mi><mn is="true">3</mn><mo is="true">+</mo></msubsup><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">âŠ•</mo><msubsup is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">,</mtext></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">Furthermore, the time-reversal symmetry operator for a spinless system is a complex conjugate operator, i.e. <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-35-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is="true">K</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-35"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">T</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">K</mi></mrow></math></script></span>. Therefore, the coexistence of time-reversal and spatial inversion symmetries (<em>PT</em>-symmetry) requires that<span class="display"><span id="fd6" class="formula"><span The basic idea for the cases of imaginary Dirac matrix is similar. This result shows that near the Î“ point, the energy gap is proportional to <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-72-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.32ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 1429.3 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(975,421)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-72"><math><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span>. As for the K point in the first BZ, we can also construct a two-band <strong><em>k</em></strong>Â·<strong><em>p</em></strong> model, due to the two-fold degeneracy near the Fermi level. At the K point, the valence and conduction bands belong to the irreducible representation <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-76-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>K</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.862ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1232.4 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(778,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">K</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-76"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">K</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow></math></script></span>, which means that the nodal surface around the K point is essential degeneracy. is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">K</mi></msup><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><msup is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">âˆ’</mo><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow></msup><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">K</mi></msup><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mo is="true">,</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mo is="true">,</mo><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">âˆ’</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mtext is="true">,</mtext></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">As a result, all of the coefficients vanish except <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-85-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>g</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></msub><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mi mathvariant=&quot;bold-italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.764ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 2481.6 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-67"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(477,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1098,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHBI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(994,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">g</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="bold-italic" is="true">k</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-85"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">g</mi><mn is="true">0</mn></msub><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mi mathvariant="bold-italic" is="true">k</mi><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math></script></span><span> under the symmetry constraints, indicating that this type of nodal surface originates from a constant Hamiltonian. Different from the conventional nodal surfaces, which are usually protected by space-time inversion and sublattice symmetries without considering <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/spin-orbit-coupling" title="Learn more about SOC from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SOC</a>, or protected by nonsymmorphic two-fold screw-rotational and time-reversal symmetries [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a><span>], tC40 is the first predicted <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a> with the nodal surfaces protected by the essential degeneracy based on group theory [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">Bulk-surface correspondence is a significant feature of a topological system. We calculate the (110) surface spectrum of tC40 and plot it in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(e) by using a tight-binding model based on maximally localized Wannier functions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. The corresponding bulk spectrum is plotted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(f) as a comparison. In this calculation, we use a ten-layer slab, and the high-symmetry <strong><em>k</em></strong> path is plotted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(b). There are distinct nearly flat bands connecting the band-crossing points in the surface spectrum, further confirming the existence of the topological nodal surfaces. While the nearly flat bands remarkably increase the density of states of the tC40's (110) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystal-surface" title="Learn more about crystal surfaces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystal surfaces</a><span>. Meanwhile, the SOC effect is also taken into consideration, and the results show that the maximum gap between the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a> and valence band of these nodal surfaces is only 1.5&nbsp;meV, which is not large enough to change the nodal-surface feature of tC40.</span></span></div></section><section id="sec3.3"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Application as an anode for SIBs</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115"><span><span>The US Advanced <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about Battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Battery</a> Consortium proposed the research target of fast-charging electric vehicle batteries within 15&nbsp;min for 80&nbsp;% pack capacity, which calls for the urgent need of novel battery </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode materials</a><span><span><span> with high <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/ion-current" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a><span> as well as high <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a>. This requirement can be met by using topological quantum materials as </span></span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode materials</a>, which are distinct from conventional metals and insulators in </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electronic-band-structure" title="Learn more about electronic band structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic band structures</a>, exhibiting intrinsically high and stable electrical conductivity protected by the topology of materials [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a><span><span>]. Next, we study the application of tC40 as an <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a><span> as its unique atomic configuration with the regularly distributed porous channels can provide the binding sites and diffusion pathways for <a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a>, and its metallic features can facilitate the diffusion of electrons and ions, showing promise for the application as an anode material. We first explore the possible adsorption sites for Na ions by introducing Na at different sites in the 1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3 supercell of tC40. During the selection of the preferable adsorption sites for a single Na atom, we optimize all the possible adsorption configurations with Na atom at the top, bridge, and hollow sites of each carbon ring in tC40, as plotted in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(a and b). After geometry optimization, we find that there are two preferred adsorption sites, namely, the hollow sites residing in the 8- and 5-membered carbon rings, labeled as H1 and H2 in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(c and d), respectively, while the <a href="/topics/chemistry/adsorption-energy" title="Learn more about adsorption energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">adsorption energy</a> is calculated by using the formula:</span><span class="display"><span id="fd23" class="formula"><span class="label">(23)</span><span
